comment._content: This, and the following 5 photos, seem to be from the same set (apparently taken at the stage door of the Metropolitan Opera in New York City. The last Bain installment posted to the Commons had 10 more from this series. Here the Met's superstar Enrico Caruso points his cane at the camera. See also and

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Eva Didur, soprano, daughter of the Polish Metropolitan bass Adam Didur, gave her début as soloist in 1918, see The New York Times, March 6, 1918 New-York tribune, May 19, 1918, Page 36, last column Olga Didur, soprano, another daughter of Adam Didur, see Time Magazine, June 30, 1930

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: William Thorner was a voice teacher and agent, see www.nytimes.com/books/first/d/drake-ponselle.html www.nytimes.com/2013/04/07/realestate/the-idea-behind-the... www.youtube.com/watch?v=9GixCw9pWv0

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The Didur daughters had not yet begun their operatic careers in 1915, but their father, Adamo Didur, sang for the Met that season. archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WS...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: "G.G. Strakosch" looks more to me like C.G. Strakhov. There was a Charles G. Strakosch who was involved in theater in New York and who was married to the singer Lillian Herlein (1895-1971) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lillian_Herlein He is pictured in this newpaper article from 1914, but it is difficult to tell if it is the same person: fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Press/...
